image.altText: Composite image of NSW Premier Chris Minns and a police officer at a media conference.

props.synopsis: NSW Police call on the public to help them identify members of the crowd who disguised themselves during Monday's riot outside a Sydney church after a bishop was stabbed.

title.children: More than 50 police injured during church riot, 16yo stabbing suspect remains in hospital

image.altText: Man looking off camera

props.synopsis: A shopping centre security guard who helped confront Bondi mass-murderer Joel Cauchi is likely to secure a permanent Australian visa, following the intervention of the prime minister.

title.children: Security guard stabbed in Bondi attack likely to get permanent visa, PM says

image.altText: A man is led to a police car by two police officers. All have blurred faces.

props.synopsis: Five Australians are among 39 individuals who have been arrested in relation to an alleged global phishing scam that targeted tens of thousands of people, the Australian Federal Police said today.

title.children: Five arrested over global phishing scam that allegedly claimed about 94,000 Australian victims

image.altText: Canberra female football players celebrating.

props.synopsis: The club's future in the A-League Women competition has been uncertain for months due to a lack of funding.

title.children: Canberra United saved from folding by last-minute funding injection from ACT government

image.altText: A child's legs seen running on the beach with water behind.

props.synopsis: A suicide prevention advocate says the death of a 10-year-old Indigenous boy who took his own life in Western Australia marks the youngest recorded suicide in child protection.

title.children: Suicide of 10yo boy under WA government's care described as 'unimaginable'

image.altText: Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel holding up cross shared by Christ the Good Shepherd Church with audio graphic below

props.synopsis: Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel says he has forgiven "whoever has done this act" and calls for his community to not retaliate.

title.children: 'I will always pray for you': Stabbed Sydney bishop forgives attacker and calls for calm

image.altText: rundle mall shoppers in rundle mall

props.synopsis: The unemployment rate increased slightly to 3.8 per cent in March, after employment fell by 7,000 people and unemployment rose by 21,000 people.

title.children: Australia's unemployment rate has risen slightly to 3.8 per cent

image.altText: Two woman walk along a path in front of the beach, one of them is pushing a pram.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence support workers could be in Australia's future if the fertility rate continues to stay the same.

title.children: There's a baby drought in Australia. Here's why you should care

image.altText: Amy, a woman with blonde hair, looks serious in a portrait.

props.synopsis: HECS-HELP debts are forecast to rise between 4.2 and 4.8 per cent this year, the second-highest rise in a decade.

title.children: 'Leave my hopes, dreams and country behind': Desperate HECS debtors brace for another large increase

image.altText: The outline of four women, kept anonymous, superimposed over shattered glass

props.synopsis: A Senate inquiry into missing and murdered First Nations women and children is meeting in Darwin today to hear from grieving families, after a 2022 Four Corners program uncovered scores of unsolved cases.

title.children: Murder and disappearance of First Nations women and children examined in Senate inquiry

image.altText: A submarine with a red, white and blue flag on the front sits on an empty patch of concrete

props.synopsis: The US Navy's head of weapons acquisitions says they have "a long ways to go" to increase shipbuilding to the necessary level to deliver on the AUKUS agreement to provide nuclear-powered submarines to Australia.

title.children: 'Does not inspire confidence': Congress committee questions US Navy heads amid AUKUS fears

image.altText: A brick house with steps up to a small porch. Police officers stand in the home's driveway.

props.synopsis: Donald Morley pleaded guilty to suffocating his 92-year-old wife, Jean Morley, with a pillow last year. A Canberra court today heard he was suffering from terminal skin cancer.

title.children: Canberra court hears 93yo man who pleaded guilty to killing his elderly wife has only months to live

image.altText: A road sign for 'State Circle', pointing to Parliament House, Queanbeyan and Cooma.

props.synopsis: The 15-year-old driver of the vehicle remains in a critical condition after the crash, which occurred on Adelaide Avenue in the early hours of this morning.

title.children: Teenaged boy in critical condition after stolen car flips outside Parliament House

image.altText: A wide road covered in water with cars and trucks stuck in the middle.

props.synopsis: Speculation swirled on social media that the weather technology was to blame for the largest ever rainfall Dubai has seen. But experts say the record rains were on a totally different scale to what seeding would produce.

title.children: Speculation 'cloud seeding' caused Dubai record rainfall and floods shot down by experts

image.altText: A close up of fidgeting hands. In the background, a psychologist watches on, taking notes.

props.synopsis: In the wake of the Bondi Junction stabbings, the Prime Minister says the government "could always do more" to address Australia's mental health crisis. It comes just a month after psychiatrists asked the government for more support.

title.children: 'Significant risk': Urgent call for more support as Australia's mental health services at crisis point

image.altText: Indonesia volcano

props.synopsis: Indonesian authorities issue a tsunami alert after eruptions at Ruang mountain send ash thousands of feet high, with hundreds evacuated from the area.

title.children: Indonesia issues tsunami alert as volcano erupts

image.altText: Man gardening with pot plants

props.synopsis: Some plants seem full of promise and intrigue at the nursery, but are full of surprises later on — when they're threatening to overthrow the boundary fence. What are the common horticultural culprits?

title.children: Are you battling one of these popular problem plants in your own backyard?

image.altText: firefighters holding hoses putting out a house fire

props.synopsis: The heritage-protected Northwood home went up in flames in September 2022, with 50 firefighters working for more than an hour to extinguish it.

title.children: Property developer pleads guilty over blaze that destroyed historic $24m Sydney mansion

image.altText: A young woman faces another person, holding her hands and mouth in movement, as if in conversation.

props.synopsis: Author Charles Duhigg and broadcaster Beverley Wang have made a profession out of having good conversations. They share how deeper listening, laughing more, and slowing down can help.

title.children: The simple skills that can help you have deeper conversations

image.altText: Four people walk along a footpath in front of the ASX building on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The ASX is trading higher after gains in iron ore, while the unemployment rate has risen to 3.8 per cent in March. It comes after the benchmark US share index posted its fourth straight day of losses. Follow the latest on our live markets blog.

title.children: Jobless queue grows by 21,000 people, ASX higher, BHP to decide Nickel West's future by August

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX continues to gain at lunch with only one sector in the red
GLAD bags manufacturer taken to court over greenwashing claims
#Breaking: Unemployment ticks higher as employment falls by 6,600 in March

image.altText: Yuja Wang plays a grand piano in front of an orchestra in a sparky red dress. Her right arm is thrown up dramatically.

props.synopsis: New York's famous Carnegie Hall tracked musician and audience heart rates during a live performance. The results show how in sync music can make us.

title.children: What tracking heart rates during a marathon concert tells us about the power of music

image.altText: Ella looks slightly to the left as she turns back while standing in a vault in her blue vault uniform.

props.synopsis: Critics and fans seem to agree that the television adaptation of Fallout doesn't miss. Here's why it's S.P.E.C.I.A.L! (that's a Fallout reference in case you didn't know).

title.children: There were fears about the Prime Video adaptation of beloved game Fallout. Here's why they nailed it

image.altText: Jauncey looks up to goal with the ball in hand

props.synopsis: Netball takes a significant step in its commitment to increase the representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander athletes, introducing an inaugural First Nations team to compete against World Cup talent at the Pacific Aus Sport Netball Series.

title.children: Australia launches inaugural First Nations team to compete on world stage in Brisbane tournament

image.altText: An AI-generated image of two people in a cafe.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence is being used to generate child abuse material, and police are increasingly worried about its spread. But AI may also be able to help investigators.

title.children: This image is AI-generated. It's innocent, but there are others police are very worried about

image.altText: Seven children in school uniform in a courtyard.

props.synopsis: After community concerns saw Gairdner Primary School lose its entire student population, hard work from staff re-engaging with parents has seen it turn the corner.

title.children: Last year this school had no students. A husband and wife team have helped bring families back

image.altText: A portrait of Sophie Kinsella smiling outside

props.synopsis: British author Sophie Kinsella, who penned the bestselling Shopaholic series, reveals she has been "diagnosed with glioblastoma, a form of aggressive brain cancer".

title.children: Sophie Kinsella, bestselling author of Shopaholic series, reveals 'aggressive' brain cancer diagnosis

image.altText: Meg Lanning looks to one side

props.synopsis: Australian cricket champ Meg Lanning reveals she was eating two small meals a day and running up to 90km a week when she took a shock break from international cricket.

title.children: Cricket champ Lanning opens up about 'unhealthy' relationship with food and exercise before shock retirement

image.altText: A red tailed black cockatoo and musk lorikeet at a wildlife sanctuary

props.synopsis: A red-tailed black cockatoo and a musk lorikeet have become inseparable, with the smaller bird often found under the wing of the cockatoo at Tasmania's Bonorong Wildlife Sanctuary.

title.children: Unlikely friendship between cockatoo and lorikeet 'bamboozles' wildlife sanctuary visitors

image.altText: Soldiers in camouflage parade holding guns

props.synopsis: Britain's foreign minister says it is clear that Israel is making a decision to act against Iran for its unprecedented strike on its territory.

title.children: Israel 'making a decision to act' against Iran, as Tehran warns of 'fierce and severe response'

image.altText: A light truck parked on the side of the road.

props.synopsis: The child has been rushed to the Queensland Children's Hospital with head injuries.

title.children: Girl, 3, in critical condition after stroller hit by truck south of Brisbane

image.altText: Jontay Porter

props.synopsis: NBA boss Adam Silver hits out at Raptors player Jontay Porter after he was caught betting against his own team and disclosing confidential information to sports bettors.

title.children: This NBA player passed on information that would have won a bettor more than $US1 million — the player has now been banned for life

image.altText: Harry in a suit exits a car.

props.synopsis: Prince Harry's lawyer says he may be "forced" to settle a lawsuit against the publisher of Rupert Murdoch's tabloid newspaper The Sun after British actor Hugh Grant agreed on a deal.

title.children: Prince Harry may have to settle Murdoch lawsuit after Hugh Grant deal, his lawyer says

image.altText: A woman in shorts crouched down

props.synopsis: An ancient sport shrouded in mystery, professional sumo wrestling in Japan is reserved only for men. A group of young female warriors wants to change that.

title.children: Hiyori lives two lives. By day, she's an office worker but by night, she's a much-feared sumo warrior
